text:
When running Tomcat 3.2.2 on Mac OS X 10.0.3, the Context Manager will 
add a context (ctx) for the parent folder's existing .DS_Store file (a file 
which is invisible to the user and used for Finder housekeeping).

Here's my setup:
PowerBook G4/256MB RAM
Mac OS X 10.0.3
Tomcat is set up in /Library/WebServer/jakarta/tomcat

To reproduce:

1) Download and install Tomcat 3.2.2 into /Library/WebServer/jakarta/
tomcat
2) Open Terminal and start Tomcat
3) Watch the startup process as it adds a context for the .DS_Store file

Here's the output from my Terminal window when starting Tomcat:

[localhost:~] cgervais% 2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding 
context Ctx( /examples )
2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding context Ctx( /admin )
Starting tomcat. Check logs/tomcat.log for error messages 
2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding context Ctx( /.DS_Store )
2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding context Ctx( /cmservlet )
2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding context Ctx(  )
2001-06-14 08:44:22 - ContextManager: Adding context Ctx( /test )
2001-06-14 08:44:24 - PoolTcpConnector: Starting 
HttpConnectionHandler on 8080
2001-06-14 08:44:24 - PoolTcpConnector: Starting 
Ajp12ConnectionHandler on 8007

This certainly isn't a show-stopping bug, but just a platform-specific 
oddity. Does Tomcat pick up .[filename] on other UNIX systems as a valid 
context?
